2.text:
The Himalayas, which stretch some 2,900 kilometres
between India, Pakistan, China, and Nepal,

9.text:
is the world’s tallest mountain range. In
addition to Mount Everest, the world’s tallest

13.text:
mountain by peak elevation standing at 8,848
meters tall, the range also features several

19.text:
other mountain peaks over 8,000 meters. It
is the only mountain range to boast mountains

24.text:
over 8,000 meters—the runner-up is a mountain
range in South America, whose tallest peak

28.text:
is just 6,962 meters tall.
Millions of years ago, these mountain peaks

34.text:
didn’t exist. The Asian continent was mostly
intact, but India was an island floating off

39.text:
the coast of Australia. Around 220 million
years ago, around the time that Pangea was

45.text:
breaking apart, India started to move northwards.
It travelled some 6,000 kilometres before

50.text:
it finally collided with Asia around 40 to
50 million years ago. Then, part of the Indian

55.text:
landmass began to go beneath the Asian one,
moving the Asian landmass up, which resulted

60.text:
in the rise of the Himalayas. It’s thought
that India’s coastline was denser and more

65.text:
firmly attached to the seabed, which is why
Asia’s softer soil was pushed up rather

69.text:
than the other way around.
The mountain range grew very rapidly in comparison

73.text:
to most mountain ranges, and it’s actually
still growing today. Mount Everest and its

77.text:
fellows actually grow by approximately a net
of about a centimetre or so every year. That’s

83.text:
in comparison to the Appalachian Mountains,
which developed some 300 million years ago

87.text:
or more, which are actually decreasing in
peak elevations as they erode.

92.text:
The continued growth in the Himalayas is likely
due to the Indian tectonic plate still moving

96.text:
slowly but surely northward. We know the plate
is still moving in part because of the frequent

101.text:
earthquakes in the region.
Now, if you do the math, you’d find that

105.text:
if the Himalayas had been growing at the current
rate for 40 million years, they should be

109.text:
about 400 km tall! If that was true, once
the infrastructure was in place, this would

114.text:
have given us a much cheaper way to put things
into low Earth orbit and beyond. (For reference,

118.text:
the International Space Station typically
orbits at between 300 km to 400 km.)

124.text:
So what happened? In part, the rate of vertical
growth has varied over time, including in

129.text:
favor of more horizontal growth. And, of course,
gravity and erosion have limited the mountains’

134.text:
growth significantly.
If you’re wondering who first figured out

137.text:
how the Himalayas formed, India merging into
Asia became the accepted theory for this formation

142.text:
around 1912. That’s when Alfred Wegener,
a German meteorologist, came up with the “Theory

147.text:
of Continental Drift” which gave us our
first ideas about Pangea, tectonic plates,

152.text:
and the thought that continents were moving
away from or closer to each other.

156.text:
What does the future for the Himalayas look
like? Undoubtedly, the mountains will continue

160.text:
to grow, though at the same time eroding too;
but the net is expected to continue to grow

165.text:
as the Indian tectonic plate doesn’t look
like it’s going to slow down any time soon.

170.text:
That means more earthquakes and, over time,
slightly taller mountains to climb.

175.text:
Bonus Facts:
• In the last century, the east coast of

177.text:
the United States has moved about 8 ft or
2.4 meters further away from Europe.

184.text:
• The fossils of sea and coastal creatures
can still be found in the Himalayas, as it

188.text:
was once two coast lines that merged together.
These fossils not only provide evidence that

192.text:
the Himalayas once existed on a coastline,
but also information about climate change

197.text:
and plate movement.
• The name for the Himalayas comes from

201.text:
the Sanskrit for snow and dwelling: “him”
and “ālaya” respectively. Essentially,

206.text:
the home of the snow.
• Mount Everest is named after one of the

211.text:
Surveyor Generals of India, George Everest.
It was not, however, Everest who first survey

216.text:
the mountain, but Andrew Waugh who took over
the role of Surveyor General after Everest.

221.text:
Waugh thought it would be a good idea to name
the mountain after his predecessor. Everest

225.text:
didn’t like the idea, but he was overruled
and his name was eventually adopted for the

229.text:
mountain by the Royal Geographical Society
in 1865.

235.text:
• While Everest is generally considered
the tallest mountain on Earth because it reaches

238.text:
the highest elevation, some argue that this
should not be the measure used, but rather

243.text:
the tallest from the base to peak. In that
case, Hawaii’s Mauna Kea would be the tallest

247.text:
at about 10,200 metres from its base on the
ocean floor to peak at 4,205 metres above

254.text:
sea level.
• Sir Edmund Hillary and Tenzing Norgay,

258.text:
his Sherpa guide, became the first people
to successfully climb to the peak of Mount

262.text:
Everest in 1953. Before Hillary, several dozen
attempts had been undertaken to climb to the

268.text:
peak since 1921. Since Hillary, nearly 3000
people have accomplished the same feat and

273.text:
around 200 have died trying.
• The Himalayas serve as a “climatic divide”

280.text:
as well as a physical barrier between India
and the rest of the continent. They prevent

284.text:
cold winter winds from entering into India
in the winter, making India warmer than other

288.text:
regions along the same lines of latitude at
that same time of the year. Similarly, they

293.text:
prevent the southern monsoon winds from taking
moisture across the border to Tibet; the result

298.text:
is India gets far more precipitation than
the relatively more arid Tibet.
